review.title: Generalized Laguerre Reduction of the Volterra Kernel for Practical Identification of Nonlinear Dynamic Systems
review.abstract: The Volterra series can be used to model a large subset of nonlinear, dynamic systems. A major drawback is the number of coefficients required model such systems. In order to reduce the number of required coefficients, Laguerre polynomials are used to estimate the Volterra kernels. Existing literature proposes algorithms for a fixed number of Volterra kernels, and Laguerre series. This paper presents a novel algorithm for generalized calculation of the finite order Volterra-Laguerre (VL) series for a MIMO system. An example addresses the utility of the algorithm in practical application.

metadata.title: Generalized Laguerre Reduction of Volterra Kernel Generalized Laguerre Reduction of the Volterra Kernel for Practical Identification of Nonlinear Dynamic Systems

sections.text: Keywords: Laguerre, model reduction, system identification, statistical learning, Volterra

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text: The first application of the Volterra series to the study of nonlinear systems was by Norbert Wiener (cf. Schetzen, 1980, p. 517). The time-invariant series can be represented by (1) the following numbers: y (t) = [t) = [t] ∞ -h1 (σ1) u (t − σ1) dσ1 + [t − σ1] [t − σ1] [t − σ1] u (t − σ1) dσ1dσ2 + · + σ1). Here u stands for the input into the system, y is the output of the system and hn is known as the ninth Volterra kernel. The modification can also be called the ninth order. sections.heading: 2. Simplifying the Volterra Series for Practical Application
sections.text: If a system is causal, meaning that at any point in time t depends only on past inputs (u (t − σ) for σ > 0 and not on future inputs (u (t − σ) for σ < 0), the Volterra series can be written as shown in eq. (2) below. Note that (2) for simplicity only includes the first term of the series. It should also be noted that all known physical systems appear to be causal. A more detailed discussion of causality can be found in Schatz (1980, p.21.89).y (t) = 0 h1 (σ1) u (t − σ1) dσ1 (2) The Volterra series can also be integral discredited by using the convolution sum instead of the convolution sum, resulting in eq. (3).

sections.heading: 2.1 Volterra Model Limitations
sections.text: This class of finite Volterra models is defined as the class of V (N, M) models by Doyle et al. (2001). In other words, N is the number of Volterra terms and M is the memory length of the system. However, with this notation it is easy to describe different Volterra models by examining the behavior of the borderline cases: V (∞, M), V (N, ∞) and V (∞, ∞) (Doyle et al., 2001, Ch. 2), (Pearson, 1999, Sec.4.2).It is important to take into account the limitations of the V (N, M) class. Some of these limitations include the inability to issue output variety (Boyd and Chua, 1985).This can be intuitively described by saying that if a system can have the same output through different local volume inputs (i.e. different constant state reactions to the same steady state), Boyd can have diversity (1985) and Boyd (1985).

sections.heading: 2.2 Volterra Model Parameterization
sections.text: Another important practical limitation, which is not dependent on application, is the parameterization of the Volterra model. In other words, how many parameters are required to define a V (N, M) model. The total number of parameters can be represented as C (N, M) (Doyle et al., 2001).The following equations describe the calculation of C (N, M).C (N, M) = M ∑ n = 0 Cn (M) (5) Cn (M) = (M + 1) nC (N, M) = 0 Cn (M).C (M + 1) N + 1 − 1 M (6) 'MNHere Cn (M) is the total number of coefficients in hn (The n-th Volterra kernel) of the Volterra model V (N, M) = M. Although Doyle et al. (2001, p. 19) methods for reducing coefficients are discussed, the relationship is still ontonal and therefore the number of processes required for an industrial barrier may grow below 250 voices.

sections.heading: 3. The Laguerre Polynomials
sections.text: Laguerre polynomials are a series of orthogonal polynomials that can be used to reduce the number of coefficients required to describe a Volterra nucleus. Applying orthogonal functions to identification and control is not new, see (Schetzen, 1980), (Dumont et al., 1991), (Zheng and Zafiriou, 1994), (Ma � kila, 1990), (Clement, 1982), (Mahmoodi et al., 2007), (Zheng and Zafiriou, 1995) and (Lee, 1960).

sections.heading: 5. Added generalization for Ease of Practical Application
sections.text: To simplify practical application, generalizations have been made to make the algorithm more scalable. Each of these generalizations is discussed separately and listed below: 1. Allow different nonlinear degrees N for each system input to i = 1... I2. Allow different Laguerre series lr for each Volterra term n = 1... N and input i = 1... I3. Allow different Laguerre timescales, i for each Laguerre series l, i r.

sections.heading: 5.1 Separate Volterra order for each system input
sections.text: The Volterra series can be used to model a large class of systems.Equation (1) (shown below for reference) is the general Volterra series of the tenth order. y (t) = и ∞ − ∞ h1 (σ1) u (t − σ2) u (t − σ1) u (t − σ2) dσ1dσ2 + · · · · + х ∞ − ∞ · ∞ − ∞ hN (σ1, · ·, σi) u (t − σ1) · · u (t − σN) dσ1 · · · dσN N = 1 is an example of the first order Volterra series and can describe systems with a linear relationship between input and output. N = 2 can describe the Volterra series relations of the second order between input and output. It cannot be assumed that in a general system all inputs will have the same relation to the output.

sections.heading: 5.2 Separate Laguerre series for each Volterra term
sections.text: Depending on the complexity of the relationship between a term of the Volterra series and the output, a different order R of the Laguerre polynomial can be used for each individual term of the Volterra series. This option allows you to use more or less Laguerre coefficients to approximate a particular term of the Volterra series as needed. A general example of an input with a straightforward first-order relationship to output and a more complicated second-order relationship to output might benefit from fewer Laguerre polynomials to approximate the first order of the Volterra kernel, and more Laguerre polynomials to approximate the second order of the Volterra kernel.

sections.heading: 5.3 Separate Laguerre time scale for each Laguerre series
sections.text: Earlier in this document, the Laguerre time scale was discussed as an important parameter in the Laguerre polynomial. Laguerre polynomial acts as a filter with a time constant of 1 / a. The time scale should be chosen as the time constant of the response to be modelled. As a separate time scale can be chosen for each Volterra term, this also allows adjustments to different reactions within the same input. Similar to the above example, one should consider an input with a low first order frequency relation to the output and a high second order frequency relation to the output. A situation that would probably occur more frequently would be two inputs with significantly different dynamics.

sections.heading: 5.5 Effect of Laguerre Reduction
sections.text: The parameterization of the Volterra series was discussed earlier in this document. It was found to be a significant obstacle to the practical application of the Volterra model due to the number of I / Os required to reliably identify such a large number of model parameters. the replacement of the Volterra core by the Laguerre polynomials allows for a reduction in the required parameters. This is because the Laguerre functions can be derived in a similar way to Q. (6) and is shown below in Q. (29). C (N, R) = R N (29) Table 2 below shows the amount of parameters in the reduced Volterra model V (N, R).

sections.heading: 5.5.1 Example - Variable Parameters
sections.text: A brief demonstration underscores the value of an algorithm that measures deviations from N, lr and an, i. Data for this example were borrowed from Bachlin et al. (2010), which is a multivariate time series for gait freezing in patients with Parkinson's disease. "Torso acceleration - horizontal forward acceleration [mg]" and "thigh acceleration - horizontal forward acceleration [mg]" were used respectively u1 (t) and u2 (t), and "ankle acceleration - horizontal forward acceleration [mg]" was y (t). Hundreds of simulations were performed using samples uniformly drawn from the following ranges: N, the nonlinear degree or volterra order was taken from integers [1, 5] for each input, and the nominal parameters were drawn from integrators [2, 4].

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, the general Volterra series was presented and some typical simplistic assumptions discussed. Limitations of the V (N, M) class Volterra series were discussed in relation to physical systems. These limitations can often be beneficial as they represent behaviors that are not common in physical systems. Perhaps the key limitation of the Volterra series is the number of parameters required to describe a model, Laguerre polynomials were introduced as a tool to estimate the Volterra cores and reduce the total number of model parameters required for a particular system. A new algorithm is presented to generalize the identification of discrete VL systems. The proposed algorithm allows the flexibility of parameterization for each class of systems that can be described by a V (N, M), l an, i r VolterraLaguerre model. An example that has used the proposed algorithm for experimental data to match the variable parameters with a higher probability of data usage.

sections.heading: Appendix A. Memory
sections.text: Fading memory systems are those where the performance has a finite, steady state, responding to a step entry. This could be the speed of a car due to an increase in the fuel that is supplied to the engine. Or the increase in flow due to a change in valve position. Fading memory and finite memory and synonymous. Any member of the class of fading memory systems can be brought to any accuracy by a finite Volterra model (Boyd and Chua, 1985). A better discussion of fading memory systems and the work on them can be found in Doyle et al. (2001, p. 41) and Boyd and Chua (1985, Sec. III). It turns out that the concept of fading memory exists at least as long as the Volterra series itself. Regularly, the horizon should be equal to the number of steps in time to steady state. In EHPC there was work that would be criteria for the choice of memory length or "Horizon" of memory systems predicting the level of this memory system itself in 1994, if this level could be.

sections.heading: Appendix B. Orthogonal and Orthonormal Functions
sections.text: Two vectors are orthogonal if they are perpendicular to each other. To test whether two vectors are perpendicular to each other, one can take the inner product of the vectors if they are perpendicular to each other. In Euclidean space, the inner product is always linearly independent, which means that one of them cannot be written as a combination of any finite combination of the other. This idea of orthogonality can be extended to functions. In other words, two functions are orthogonal if their inner product is approximately the same. An orthogonal set is a group of vectors that are orthogonal to each other. For orthogonal functions, the orthogonal condition can be expressed as eq.

Grade is called the polynomial n. Laguerre. It is also interesting that the Laguerre function ln (t) n has zero intersections defined by the zeros of Ln (t). Further details on the derivation and properties of Laguerre polynomials and functions can be found in Schetzen (1980, chapter 16) and Lee (1960, chapter 18,5).

referenceMentions.context: Some of these limitations include not being able to exhibit output multiplicity (Boyd and Chua, 1985).
1 Volterra Model Limitations This class of finite Volterra models is defined as the class of V(N,M) models by Doyle et al. (2001). Where N is the nonlinear degree and M is the dynamic order.

Some of these limitations include not being able to exhibit output multiplicity (Boyd and Chua, 1985). This can be described intuitively by saying that if a system can exhibit the same output by different local inputs (i.e. different steady state responses to the same steady state input), it must have had paths that differed initially. This leads to a similar conclusion which says conditionally stable impulse responses cannot be described by a fading memory Volterra model. Volterra models also cannot produce persistent oscillations or chaos in response to asymptotically constant input sequences. The limitations of the Volterra series can be seen as beneficial or detrimental depending on the desired output of the model. If a model for a system with persistent oscillations is desired then VL models should not be used. However, it is useful to have a model that implicitly rejects these types of characteristics if the physical system does not exhibit them. More information on this subject can be found in Doyle et al. (2001); Pearson (1999)

A better discussion of fading memory systems and the work done on them can be found in Doyle et al. (2001, p. 41),and Boyd and Chua (1985, Sec. III). It turns out that the concept of fading memory has been around at least as long as the Volterra series itself. In EHPC there has been work suggesting criteria for choosing the memory length or “Horizon” of finite memory systems, see Kong and De Keyser (1994) for more details and references.

metadata.abstractText: The Volterra series can be used to model a large subset of nonlinear, dynamic systems. A major drawback is the number of coefficients required model such systems. In order to reduce the number of required coefficients, Laguerre polynomials are used to estimate the Volterra kernels. Existing literature proposes algorithms for a fixed number of Volterra kernels, and Laguerre series. This paper presents a novel algorithm for generalized calculation of the finite order Volterra-Laguerre (VL) series for a MIMO system. An example addresses the utility of the algorithm in practical application.
